DataElement.preferredName: Donor Cellular Infusion Source Isolation From Whole Blood Unit Blood Component Tranfusion Unit Number
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A form of adoptive immunotherapy used after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Lymphocytes from the original stem cell donor are given to the HSCT recipient, after the transplant, to augment an antitumor immune response (graft-versus-tumor), or ensure that the donor stem cells remain engrafted. Although lymphocytes are the most commonly used cell, other cells including fibroblasts, mesenchymal or dendritic cells may be delivered to affect chimerism, treat Graft vs. Host Disease, treat viral infections or Post Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disease or other novel uses under investigation._Where something is available or from where it originates._A state of separation; the act of isolating something; setting something apart from others; marked by separation of or from usually contiguous elements._Used to indicate a specified place or time as a starting point; used to indicate a source, cause, agent, or instrument._Blood that has not been separated into its various components; blood that has not been modified except for the addition of an anticoagulant._A single undivided thing occurring in the composition of something else._Number of blood component units transfused into a person.
